name: Domestic Hot Water Recirculation: Why It Matters

quiz.question: On average, how much bigger are homes today than they were in the 70s?
quiz.feedback: In the 1970s the average home was 1,600 sqaure feet. Homes today average 2,400 square feet.

quiz.question: According to the Department of Energy (DOE), how many gallons of water does the average family use in a day?
quiz.feedback: The average family uses about 60 gallons of water each day.

quiz.question: The DOE estimates a family of 4 can send how many gallons down the drain while waiting for hot qater to arrive.
quiz.feedback: The average family of 4 wastes about 12,000 gallons of water per year waiting for hot water.

quiz.question: In the 1970's, the pipe run to the farthest fixture averaged 30 feet.  In homes built today the distance averages:
quiz.feedback: The distance from the water heater to the fathest fixture has almost tripled, from 30 feet in the 70's to 80-90 feet today.

quiz.question: According to DOE estimates, approximately how much of the money spent on hot water is wasted?
quiz.feedback: Leaving fixtures open while waiting for hot water to arrive can waste as much as 1/3 of every domestic hot water dollar.

quiz.question: A recirculation system with a central manifold and hot and cold lines going out to the fixtures is called:
quiz.feedback: A Home run system configuration has a central manifold with hot and cold lines going to the fixtures.

quiz.question: Half-loop recirculation is more efficient than full-loop recirculation.
quiz.feedback: Half-loop configurations save energy by using an aquastat to shut the pump off as soon as there's hot water at the farthest fixture.

quiz.question: Aquastats can be installed at the water heater or the farthest fixture.
quiz.feedback: Aquastats should be installed just before or just after the farthest fixture.

quiz.question: Timer based recirculation is a good choice for tankless systems.
quiz.feedback: If the timer tells the tankless water heater to run when you actually don't need hot water, you'll end up short-cycling the heater and shorten its life.

quiz.question: The digital version of Taco's Plumb n' Plug can handle how many events each day?
quiz.feedback: The Plumb n' Plug with the digital timer can handle up to 7 separate events a day, for a total of 49 events a week.

quiz.question: The SmartPlus can be used with or without a dedicated recirculation line.
quiz.feedback: The SmartPlus has to have a recirculation line.  So it's not an option for retrofits, unless you have a relatively easy way to install one.

quiz.question: Using the sensor with the SmartPlus will improve its performance, but installation is optional.
quiz.feedback: For the SmartPlus to function properly, you must use the sensor.

quiz.question: The SmartPlus cycles at this rate:
quiz.feedback: The SmartPlus cycles at a rate of 2-1/2 minutes on and 10 minutes off.

quiz.question: Which of the following is NOT a hot water event?
quiz.feedback: A quick hand washing would not last long enough for the SmartPlus to recognize it as a hot water event.

quiz.question: The TacoGenie can be used with or without a dedicated return line.
quiz.feedback: The TacoGenie is capable of using the cold water return line as a return, as well as a dedicated line.

quiz.question: The TacoGenie cannot be used with tankless systems.
quiz.feedback: The TacoGenie has the versatility to handle both traditional and tankless DHW systems.

quiz.question: How long is the lockout period on the TacoGenie?
quiz.feedback: There is an 8 minute lockout period before the TacoGenie can be reactivated.

quiz.question: The TacoGenie will not operate if the temperature of the water on the inlet side reaches:
quiz.feedback: The TacoGenie has a fail-safe feature that will prevent it from operating if the temperature on the inlet side ever reaches 100 degrees.

quiz.question: When you open a fixture and wait for hot water, how many gallons are you wasting?
quiz.feedback: Waiting for hot water wastes about 3 gallons per minute.

quiz.question: Depending on where you live and your lifestyle, domestic hot water can consume what portion of your energy cost?
quiz.feedback: On average DHW accounts for about a quarter of your energy costs.

quiz.question: The most common plumbing configuration is:
answers: Home Run (Central manifold with supply lines)
quiz.feedback: Traditional trunk and branch is still the most common configuration.

quiz.question: A common recirculation setup in new homes is:
answers: Half-loop using the cold water line as a return
quiz.feedback: Full-loop recirculation is common in new construction, because it's easy to run the piping.

quiz.question: Some half-loop recirculation systems use the cold water line as a return.
quiz.feedback: Half-loop systems can either use an aquastat with a dedicated return line, or use the cold water line for recirculation.

quiz.question: The best place to install an aquastat is at the water heater.
quiz.feedback: An aquastat should be installed at the farthest fixture, so it can shut off the pump as soon as the water is hot.

quiz.question: Aquastats can only be used with the digital version of the Plumb n' Plug.
quiz.feedback: Aquastats can be used with both the analog and digital models of the Plumb n' Plug.

quiz.question: Most recirculation pumps have this type of timer:
answers: Half use analog, half use digital
quiz.feedback: Most pumps use a 24 hour analog timer.  The Plumb n' Plug is available in both analog and digital versions.

quiz.question: In systems with both aquastats and timers, it's the aquastat that controls when the pump will shut off.
quiz.feedback: Once water at the farthest fixture is hot enough, the aquastat will shut off the pump.

quiz.question: In Pulse Mode, the SmartPlus runs approximately how many minutes out of every hour?
quiz.feedback: The SmartPlus operates on a 2-1/2 minutes on and 10 minutes off cycle. So it runs only about 4 times an hour for a total of 10 minutes.

quiz.question: How soon before a hot water event does the SmartPlus begin to pulse?
quiz.feedback: The SmartPlus pulses over a two-hour window that starts one hour before the event, and ends one hour after.

quiz.question: The Hot-Link crossover valve can be installed either under the sink or at the hot water heater.
quiz.feedback: The Hot-Link valve goes under the sink, and the 006 pump gets installed at the water heater.

quiz.question: The Hot-Link is designed to work with the 006 Plumb n' Plug.
quiz.feedback: The 006 has more than enough capacity to handle as many Hot-Link valves as you want to install.

quiz.question: The Hot-Link crossover valve combines a wax element with a thermal sensor.
quiz.feedback: The Hot-Link replaces trouble-prone wax elements with a durable sensor disk.

quiz.question: How many Hot-Link valves can you use with one controller?
quiz.feedback: You can use as many Hot-Link valves as you want.

quiz.question: The Hot-Link is available in only one configuration, for use with the 006 circulator.
quiz.feedback: The 006 is more than adequate.  The 008 or 0011 configurations would be overkill.

quiz.question: Designing a commercial HVAC system is purely a technical process.
quiz.feedback: There are many other subjective factors that have to be considered.

quiz.question: When designing a commercial HVAC system, the engineer must consider a variety of factors in addition to the technical requirements of the system.
quiz.feedback: The engineer does have to consider a variety of factors over and above the technical aspects, such as the intended use of the building, whether it will be owner-occupied and many more.

quiz.question: It's important for the HVAC engineer to understand the business case for the project when designing the HVAC system.
quiz.feedback: No matter what else it does, an HVAC system has to fit into the overall business case for the building.

quiz.question: The developer of a commercial rental property is likely to have a relatively short-term interest in the project.
quiz.feedback: The business case for most developers is to build, stabalizem and sell at a profit.

quiz.question: We can evaluate the design of an HVAC system by how well it achieves its' intended purpose.
quiz.feedback: If an HVAC system is achieving its' intended purpose it is properly designed.

quiz.question: The principles of good design don't apply to a commercial HVAC system.
quiz.feedback: The principles of good design apply no matter what you're designing.

quiz.question: A good HVAC system design:
answers: Will take advantage of physical laws (i.e., heat rises)
quiz.feedback: A well designed HVAC system will accomplish all of these goals.

quiz.question: When choosing the distribution for a system, the fundamental choice is water-based or air-based.
quiz.feedback: A quick hand washing would not last long enough for the SmartPlus to recognize it as a hot water event.

quiz.question: Which type of commercial HVAC system is the most energy efficient?
answers: All are about equal in energy efficiency
quiz.feedback: Hydronic systems are more energy efficient for several reasons.

quiz.question: Hydronic systems are generally more comfortable for occupants.
quiz.feedback: Hydronic heat is more even and doesn't create drafts, so occupants tend to be more comfortable.

quiz.question: Water source heat pumps utilize a reversible refrigerant cycle to provide both heating and cooling.
quiz.feedback: A reversable refrigerant cycle is needed to provide both heating and cooling.

quiz.question: One drawback of water source heat pumps is noise, if they are not strategically located.
quiz.feedback: Water source heat pumps are noisy if not strategically located.

quiz.question: Geothermal heat pumps transfer heat to or from the earth itself for heating and cooling.
quiz.feedback: Geothermal heat pumps give and take heat to and from the earth.

quiz.question: VAV systems deliver supply air at one temperature to all zones throughout a building.
quiz.feedback: VAV units each need a heater.

quiz.question: Active chilled beams and radiant heating used separately or together make use of natural induction air flow to accomplish heating and cooling.
quiz.feedback: Since these systems use natural induction air flow the energy costs are much less then comparable systems.

quiz.question: Component size affects system costs in terms of:
quiz.feedback: Component size affects a wide range of system costs.

quiz.question: Some types of HVAC systems are clearly superior to others in all applications.
quiz.feedback: No one type of HVAC system is best in every kind of application.

quiz.question: In terms of first costs, water source heat pumps are less expensive than either variable air volume (VAV) or chilled beam systems.
quiz.feedback: VAV system first costs are less expensive than the other systems we compared.

quiz.question: Among the 3 systems, chilled beams have higher first costs but the lowest system life cycle costs.
quiz.feedback: Chilled beam systems are the most efficient.

quiz.question: HVAC systems with lower first costs tend to have higher operating costs
quiz.feedback: An up-front investment in a more efficient system will lower the operating costs.

quiz.question: In addition to technical requirements, a proposed HVAC system must take into consideration:
answers: The owner's assumptions and expectations for the building
The owner's evaluation of first costs versus operating costs
Whether the building will be owner-occupied or rented
quiz.feedback: All of these and many more factors must be taken into consideration when designing an HVAC system.

quiz.question: When presenting a proposed HVAC system it's most important to emphasize the technical sophistication of the system.
quiz.feedback: Most owners are far more interested in system performance and costs than the technology itself.

quiz.question: When designing a commercial HVAC system, financial and business factors are less important than the technical factors.
quiz.feedback: It's best for the HVAC professional to understand the broad business and financial context of the project.

quiz.question: When designing a commercial HVAC system, the engineer must be clear about what commercial benefit the owner expects to realize.
quiz.feedback: The engineer must know all of the owner's goals before designing and HVAC system.

quiz.question: Owners generally name cost as their first priority for a commercial HVAC system.
quiz.feedback: Owners will often put comfort at the top of their list until they start to look at the price of the system.  Then cost becomes their number one concern.

quiz.question: When designing an HVAC system, the engineer is well-served to recognize the point of view, assumptions, opinions, etc.—that he or she brings to the project.
quiz.feedback: A good enginner must recognize all of these things in order to design the best system possible.

quiz.question: A properly designed HVAC system will be sized:
answers: To fit primarily based on the project budget
To provide sufficient occupant comfort without reducing system efficiency
To reduce the carbon footprint, even at the expense of some occupant comfort
quiz.feedback: A properly designed HVAC system will provide comfort without wasting energy.

quiz.question: Old design axioms such as Less is more, and Form follows function, are less important when it comes to a highly technical design such as a commercial HVAC system.
quiz.feedback: Those design principles hold just as true for an HVAC system as any other design.

quiz.question: The major objectives of any commercial HVAC system include:
answers: Creating a system that is easy to work with and monitor
Using an energy source that is readily available, cost effective and clean
quiz.feedback: All of these should be major objectives when designing an HVAC system.

quiz.question: When designing an HVAC system,  it’s good practice to identify the best energy source available and design the system to utilize that energy source.
quiz.feedback: You want to build in the flexibility to use various energy sources as prices, availability and other factors change.

quiz.question: The HVAC system designer’s most fundamental decision is whether the system will be air based or water based
quiz.feedback: Deciding between a water or air based system is the most fundamental decision an HVAC system designer will make.

quiz.question: Because air is less dense than water, it is a more efficient medium for moving BTU’s in an HVAC system.
quiz.feedback: Water is a far more efficient medium for transferring BTUs.

quiz.question: Hydronic systems require substantially less energy than a comparable air system to move the same amount of heat.
quiz.feedback: Energy costs are higher for large fan motors than small circulator motors.

quiz.question: Hydronic system piping leaves more usable space for owners and occupants than air-based systems.
quiz.feedback: Hydronic piping takes up much less space than large air system ductwork.

quiz.question: Air-based systems are easy to modify for use with alternative energy sources.
quiz.feedback: Air-based systems are not flexible enough to easily modify to use alternative energy sources.

quiz.question: Active chilled beams:
answers: Use only natural convection for circulation of room air
Require a fan for circulation of room air
quiz.feedback: Chilled beams provide ventilation, heating and cooling.

quiz.question: The majority of installed commercial HVAC systems are air-based because it isn’t possible to provide cooling with a hydronic system.
quiz.feedback: Hydronic systems can be used for cooling, as we’ve seen with chilled beams.

quiz.question: Air systems generally require about three times as much energy to move the same amount of heat as a comparable hydronic system.
quiz.feedback: Air systems are less efficient than hydronic systems.

quiz.question: Which type of system generally provides the best occupant comfort?
answers: They are all about the same
quiz.feedback: Chilled beams are more comfortable because they provide even temperatures.

quiz.question: Hydronic systems also need an “air side” to provide ventilation.
quiz.feedback: All systems need some sort of air side to provide ventilation.

quiz.question: Chilled beams are suitable for providing both heating and cooling.
quiz.feedback: Chilled beams can provide both heating and cooling.

quiz.question: When chilled beams are used for heating as well as cooling, they generally require supplemental heating.
quiz.feedback: Chilled beams generally require some sort of supplemental heating.

quiz.question: Generally, active chilled beams provide enough heating capacity for perimeter areas.
quiz.feedback: Perimeter area are where chilled beams do not provide enough heating capacity.

quiz.question: The lowest first costs will always provide the best return on investment over the life of a building.
quiz.feedback: Lower first costs in no way assure a better return on investment over the life of the building.

quiz.question: One drawback of water source heat pumps is that they don’t allow individual zone temperature control.
quiz.feedback: Water source heat pumps do allow individual zone temperature control, like a unit in a hotel room.
